dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so B, you know, for ages, everyone's been saying, like, once the economy really recovers from the pandemic, we're gonna see this *huge* wave of people changing jobs, right? Like, the floodgates opening.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so B, you know, for ages, everyone's been saying, like, once the economy really recovers from the pandemic, we're gonna see this huge wave of people changing jobs, right? Like, the floodgates opening.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Combine that with pent-up demand from workers whose job searches were put on hold due to the pandemic, and from employers who have struggled to fill white collar and service jobs alike, and it would seem natural to assume that the floodgates will soon open.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. That was the, um, the conventional wisdom, wasn't it? Like, pent-up demand from workers, employers scrambling. But apparently, that might not actually be the case.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. That was the, um, the conventional wisdom, wasn't it? Like, pent-up demand from workers, employers scrambling. But apparently, that might not actually be the case.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But that may not be the case.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which is kinda wild, because you'd think, right? But the article points out this recession has been, like, really different from others.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is kinda wild, because you'd think, right? But the article points out this recession has been, like, really different from others.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The pandemic-driven recession hasnt been like most economic downturns

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, the stock market's booming, housing's up, retail sales rebounded really quickly. It's not your typical downturn at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, the stock market's booming, housing's up, retail sales rebounded really quickly. It's not your typical downturn at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the stock and housing markets have boomed, and after an initial shock last spring, retail sales have quickly rebounded.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And the labor market, uh, is actually pretty hot. Like, tightness is almost back to pre-pandemic levels. And voluntary quitting? That's really recovered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the labor market, uh, is actually pretty hot. Like, tightness is almost back to pre-pandemic levels. And voluntary quitting? That's really recovered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: While the U.S. lost 8.5 million jobs from February 2020 to February 2021, the labor market is hot. Tightness, an economic indicator that tracks the ratio of job vacancies to unemployment, has virtually returned to pre-pandemic levels. Especially unusual is the rate at which employees are voluntarily quitting their jobs recovered in September.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Right? Like, employers who are, um, worrying about retaining talent *in a few months*? They're already behind. It's happening *now*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? Like, employers who are, um, worrying about retaining talent in a few months? They're already behind. It's happening now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Employers worrying about how theyll retain talent in a few months are already behindthey need to have it figured out now.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! Professor Michael Brown from Harvard says it doesn't look like people who want to leave are waiting. So why is it so tight then? Because unemployment numbers don't tell the whole story, do they?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! Professor Michael Brown from Harvard says it doesn't look like people who want to leave are waiting. So why is it so tight then? Because unemployment numbers don't tell the whole story, do they?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We arent in the normal dynamic, says Eliza Forsythe, a professor at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, who has studied the pandemic labor market. At this point, it doesnt look like people who want to leave their jobs are waiting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, not at all. Apparently, like, five million Americans have just left the job market entirely since the pandemic started. They're not even counted in that unemployment figure.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, not at all. Apparently, like, five million Americans have just left the job market entirely since the pandemic started. They're not even counted in that unemployment figure.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The five million Americans who have left the job market altogether since the start of the pandemic, according to the Federal Reserve, are not counted in that figure.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, five million. That's huge. And I guess people's attitudes towards work have really shifted too, huh?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, five million. That's huge. And I guess people's attitudes towards work have really shifted too, huh?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Peoples attitudes toward work have also changed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. After a year of being, like, unemployed or working from home, people have totally recalibrated what they expect from employers. And their own priorities.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. After a year of being, like, unemployed or working from home, people have totally recalibrated what they expect from employers. And their own priorities.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After a year spent unemployed or working from home, many have recalibrated the expectations they have of employers and the priorities they have for themselves.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, applications to law and medical school are up a lot, which is a sign people are completely rethinking their careers. Plus, uh, 2.4 million fewer mothers in the workforce.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, applications to law and medical school are up a lot, which is a sign people are completely rethinking their careers. Plus, uh, two point four million fewer mothers in the workforce.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: while there are now 1.4 million fewer mothers in the workforce than there were in early 2020.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's a big one. And then, you know, some jobs, like in hospitality, just aren't viable for everyone right now with the health risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a big one. And then, you know, some jobs, like in hospitality, just aren't viable for everyone right now with the health risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: a good number of jobs, like those in the hospitality and restaurant industries, simply arent viable for everyone given the continued health risks of Covid-19.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Good point. And what about all the talk about young people just, like, jumping ship?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Good point. And what about all the talk about young people just, like, jumping ship?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the article says to take that with a grain of salt. Young people generally *do* have high turnover rates. It's not necessarily just a pandemic thing, you know?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the article says to take that with a grain of salt. Young people generally do have high turnover rates. It's not necessarily just a pandemic thing, you know?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Surveys that indicate young people will be particularly likely to leave their jobs should be taken with a grain of salt. In 2019, well before the pandemic, a whopping 74% of Millennials anticipated leaving their jobs in the next three years. In general, young people have pretty high turnover rates, says Forsythe.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, fair enough. So, if a mass exodus isn't super likely, but the market *is* tight, what should employers be doing, then? To retain people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, fair enough. So, if a mass exodus isn't super likely, but the market is tight, what should employers be doing, then? To retain people?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Flexibility, A. That's huge. Like, Microsoft, Amazon, Google â€“ they're all doing hybrid or even indefinite work-from-home.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Flexibility, A. That's huge. Like, Microsoft, Amazon, Google - they're all doing hybrid or even indefinite work-from-home.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Microsoft and Salesforce, for example, are adopting permanent hybrid work models, while others like Dropbox, Twitter and Shopify will let their employees work from home indefinitely.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, accommodating changing needs is key. And things like childcare assistance, extra parental leave...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, accommodating changing needs is key. And things like childcare assistance, extra parental leave...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Childcare assistance, additional maternity or paternity leave, or subsidized tutoring can [also] be a huge differentiator for the employers offering them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: [overlapping] Absolutely. And money, too. Wages are up, and companies like Target are giving big bonuses.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And money, too. Wages are up, and companies like Target are giving big bonuses.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In December, Walmart announced that it would pay its 1.5 million retail workers another $700 million in cash bonuses, contributing to a yearly total of $2.8 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right. Because, I mean, replacing an employee can cost *twice* their annual salary. So a bonus is a smart investment.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right. Because, I mean, replacing an employee can cost twice their annual salary. So a bonus is a smart investment.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the cost of replacing an employee can amount to twice their annual salary, a one-time bonus could be a critical long-term investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. It's causing a lot of anxiety for leaders right now, uh, but the solutions are kinda clear: invest in your people, and do it *now*.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. It's causing a lot of anxiety for leaders right now, uh, but the solutions are kinda clear: invest in your people, and do it now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The potential for turnover is a major issue causing anxiety for leaders right now, says McDonald.
